Forms collective nouns, almost always neuter gender. Whenever possible, the root vowel is modified as well: Ader/Geäder, Ast/Geäst, Berg/Gebirge, Busch/Gebüsch, Rippe/Gerippe, Stein/Gestein, Strauch/Gesträuch, Wasser/Gewässer, Wolke/Gewölk; Forms action nouns, usually with a sense of repetition or continuation. All of these nouns are neuter and have no plural. For example: ächzen/Geächze, heulen/Geheule/Geheul, reden/Gerede, seufzen/Geseufze; Forms nomina rei actae, verbal nouns that refer to the patient of the action, always of neuter gender. For example: schenken/Geschenk, legen/Gelege, prägen/Gepräge; Forms past participles in combination with a suffix -en or -(e)t: schlafen/geschlafen, denken/gedacht, retten/gerettet. Nouns are frequently made from the past participle; Forms verbs with terminative aktionsart: geleiten, genießen, gebären, gelangen, gereuen, geziemen, geruhen, genesen. This is hardly productive after Early New High German and outside of dialects
